The patient is a ___ year old male with medical history for chronic lower back pain who now presents with complaint of right lower quadrant/flank abdominal pain since this morning.  According to the patient, he was feeling well until yesterday afternoon, when he developed acute-onset of back pain. He does have a history of chronic lower back pain with multiple surgical interventions, however he states that the quality of the pain during this episode was different than his usual pain. These symptoms continued through-out the night, and this morning he noted that the discomfort had localized to the right lower quadrant/flank instead. At this time he also began experiencing some mild nausea, but no emesis. Due to the unusual and non-resolving nature of his symptoms, he presented to the ED for further evaluation.  He denies any fever or chills, has had normal bowel movements, and normal appetite (indeed, the patient reports feeling quite hungry). No recent sick contacts. No other associated systemic symptoms. A TTE showed no evidence of  vegetation. A chest CT demonstrated evidence of a possible RLL  pneumonia so she was treated w/ a 14 day course of levofloxacin.  Ultimately, no definitive etiology for her fevers was determined  and she was discharged home. She was readmitted ___ with  fevers. She underwent Doppler renal US, CXR, ECHO,CT abdomen, US  of her AVF and a PET scan all of which were negative. She has  also been tested for EBV, CMV, parvovirus, aspergillus  galactomannan. All teams involved (transplant nephrology, ID,  surgery) have been suspicious about her embolized kidney as the  source of the fevers either because of rejection or infection in  a necrotic kidney and there was consideration of kidney biopsy  with cultures but this was not performed and she was placed on  Levofloxacin as above.   . HPI:  Mr ___ is a ___ year old male with a history of recently  diagnosed pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor and coronary artery  disease who presents with fever, shaking chills, and syncopal  episode this morning.     One night prior to admission, Mr ___ had a fever and chills;  while in the shower this morning, he felt cold and dizzy and  felt himself fall.  His wife noted that he hit his head.  They  deny any convulsions, urinary, or bowel incontinence.   Unclear  if he lost consciousness.  EMS arrived and checked a blood  pressure and noted it to be 80/54 with heart rate of 60.   Blood  sugar was 110.  He was seen at the emergency department at  ___ where blood cultures were drawn. An EKG revealed left  axis but was otherwise normal.  Unclear if a head CT was  performed.  He was then transferred to ___ for further  management.  On morning of admission, he received an ERCP given  his fevers; however, of note, he had no significant abdominal  pain and his bilirubin was 2.4 (the lowest in the past several  weeks).   On ERCP, a single stricture was noted in the lower  part of the CBD; the two existing plastic stents were removed  and a metal stent was positioned into place.  He was then  transferred to the floor for further management.   Review of systems revealed no cough, chest pain, nausea,  vomiting, diarrhea, dysuria, rash, joint pain, swelling,  headaches, or visual changes.  He did endorse bloating.   No  progressive jaundice or change in color of urine or stools.  At  time of transfer to floor, denied chills or fever.     Regarding his history of newly diagnosed pancreatic  neuroendocrine tumor, he had noted approximately one month of  weight loss, progressive jaundice, decreased appetite, and ___  colored stools who was admitted for this from ___. His  bilirubin was as high as 11.2 with an alkaline phosphatase of  1473. He underwent several studies including MRCP on ___, which  showed two liver lesions in segments VIII and ___, 1.7 and 1.3 cm in size, and soft tissue density at the hepatic hilum, likely a combination and lymphadenopathy and tumor causing biliary dilation. Soft tissue signal was seen anterior to the uncinate process and surrounding the gastroduodenal artery, and between pancreatic neck/gastric antrum. Multiple enlarged periceliac, portacaval, and porta hepatis nodes were seen measuring up to 2 cm on the short axis. ERCP on ___ showed a 3 cm stricture at  the lower third of the common bile duct and a 2 cm stricture at the main pancreatic duct, and plastic stents were placed at both locations. EUS on ___ noted an ill-defined mass at the porta hepatis and lymph node at the porta hepatis without discrete pancreatic mass seen. CTA abdomen on ___ showed an irregular, lobulated mass centered at the biliary hilum infiltrating along the central biliary tree and into the head of the pancreas, with encasement of the common hepatic artery, gastroduodenal artery, and hepatic artery proper. Enhancing segment VIII and segment  ___ liver lesions were felt suspicious for metastases.   ___ lymph node biopsy from the EUS shows a high-grade neuroendocrine tumor, with Ki-67 of ~50%, with tumor cells positive for CK7, chromogranin, and CDX-2, and negative for TTF-1, synaptophysin, and CK20.     Past Medical History: Type 2 DM CAD s/p CABG x 4 ((LIMA_D1, SVG-dLAD, RPDA, and OME) in ___ hyperlipidemia exercise induced asthma left shoulder Zoster gout iron deficiency anemia   Social History: ___ Family History: Patient notes one uncle had a hepatoma of uncertain etiology,  another uncle with a history of lymphoma.

Past Medical History: Per OMR ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: - ___: Presented emergently to ___ with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and aspiration pneumonia, all of which had been escalating over the course of a week prior to his presentation and preceded by an unintentional weight loss of about ___ pounds over the prior couple of weeks. CT scan showed a distended stomach with thickening of the gastric antrum, but  no evidence of distant metastases and no radiographic evidence of local regional lymphadenopathy.  Upper endoscopy reportedly showed a mass in the gastric antrum biopsy which reportedly confirmed adenocarcinoma.   - ___: Taken to the operating room at ___ with surgeon Dr. ___ and underwent a subtotal gastrectomy with Billroth I reconstruction.  Intraoperatively, Dr. ___ describes no visible evidence of peritoneal metastases. There was apparently note made of a "nodule" within the resected part of the stomach that was separate from the tumor itself.  By the outside hospital pathology report, the gastric tumor  specimen showed a 5.5 cm intestinal type, poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma invading into the subserosal connective tissue (pT3).  Surgical margins are described as negative, however, per the pathology note "a small focus of intermixed crushed epithelial cells with associated inflammation" is seen in the perigastric fat on one of the shaved distal margin permanent sections (slide ___.  Most of these cells are bland, but a  few atypical cells are seen.  Overall, they morphologically appeared dissimilar to the high-grade cytology seen in the poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma, but the crushed nature of this focus makes interpretation difficult.  These cells were not seen on the corresponding intraoperative frozen section slide  and are not seen on deeper levels.  The significance of this focus  is unclear, but the possibility that this focus represents adenocarcinoma at the distal margin is not favored.  The slide with this focus was reviewed interdepartmentally."  There was lymphovascular invasion. Five out of 17 lymph nodes were  involved by metastatic adenocarcinoma (pN2).  The "gastric nodule" was found to be 0.55 cm gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) with 1 mitosis per 20 high-powered fields, which was focally present at a cauterized specimen margin.  Per the outside hospital  pathology report, HER-2/neu expression was negative by  immunohistochemistry and non amplified by FISH analysis (ratio of 1.2).  - ___: Began cycle 1 of adjuvant chemotherapy with epirubicin (50 mg/m2 on day 1), cisplatin (60 mg/m2 on day 1), and capecitabine (1000 mg PO q12h on days ___ on 21-day cycles - ___: Began adjuvant chemoradiation with capecitabine 1000 mg PO BID as a radiosensitizer. Completed 45 Gy on ___. In ___, he had recurrence of a  cutaneous eruption involving the right cheek, but evaluation was  felt inconsistent with recurrent herpes zoster and biopsies  supported a clonal low-grade B-cell lymphoproliferation, perhaps  "marginal zone B-cell lymphoma," reviewed by dermatologist Dr.  ___ at ___.  (2) This right face cutaneous eruption waxed and waned in early  ___, extending to involve the right nostril and skin to the  left of midline underneath the nose. In follow-up evaluation a  CBC showed leukocytosis (WBC = 22.7K), but differential was not  obtained. He saw Dr. ___ in follow-up who performed skin  lesional punch biopsy of the superior nasolabial crease on  ___. This showed skin involvement by CLL, without evidence of  transformation.  (3) Subsequently, he saw Dr. ___ at ___, and flow  cytometry of peripheral blood on ___ confirmed a lymphocyte  predominance by CLL; 3% of cells were positive for CD38. On  ___, torso CT scan at ___ showed extensive lymphadenopathy  at multiple sites throughout the upper neck, chest, abdomen and  pelvis, as summarized in my ___ note.  (4) Repeat CBCs in ___ again showed leukocytosis with  lymphocyte predominance on differential. He saw hematologist Dr. ___ for a second opinion. At ___, WBCs = 13.6 and 17.9K with 76% and 66% lymphocytes on ___ and ___, respectively. Flow cytometry at ___ again confirmed CLL; however, 50% of B cells were CD38 positive. (5) In ___, he developed fevers and constitutional symptoms  with marked fatigue and weight loss. On evaluation by Dr. ___  ___ at ___, concern was raised regarding transformation of his CLL, and repeat torso CT scan was obtained on ___, showing interval increase in some but not all areas of lymphadenopathy, as summarized in my ___ note. However, subsequent evaluation by infectious disease specialist Dr. ___ at ___ disclosed erlichiosis, and therapy with doxycycline was begun.  By ___, he had noted marked improvement in his constitutional symptoms with resolution of fevers and stabilization of his weight, having had a 15-pound weight loss during his ___ illness.  (6) In ___, he developed bilateral otitis media, worse on the right, complicated by tympanic membrane perforation. Throughtout ___ and ___ he noted progressive DOE. He saw Dr. ___ at ___ on ___ who noted 2 cm submandibular and inguinal lymph nodes, in addition to small anterior and  posterior cervical and bilateral axillary lymph nodes. Chest exam was clear. WBC was now 60K, representing a tripling in WBC over 4 months. Peripheral blood FISH analysis on CLL cells was obtained showing abnormalities for the D13S319 13q14.3 and P53 17p13.1 probes in ___ and 70/100 nuclei, respectively.  (7) In ___, he met pulmonologist Dr. ___ and cardiologist Dr. ___, who diagnosed and managed CHF. On lasix, he felt improved shortness of breath. However, on ___ and ___ he experienced "crashing" fevers and sweats. With progressive dyspnea, he was found to have markedly increased  left pleural effusion and posterior pericardial effusion with RV collapse. Admitted to hospital on ___, he ultimately underwent placement of a pericardial window, with drainage of left pleural and pericardial fluid, both showing CLL cells. However, evaluation of pericardial tissue showed organizing fibrinous material with entrapped mixed inflammatory cells, including numerous small lymphocytes consistent with CLL cells. However, there was no evidence of Richter's transformation or otherwise, and CLL cells were regarded as "bystanders." The overall findings were those of an "organizing pericarditis, the cause of which is unclear." Of note, multiple specimens for various infectious diseases (see OMR) were negative except for ___ B4 and B5 antibodies which were "8" rather than "less than 8." (8) On ___, he was admitted to hospital from ___ to ___ with progressive dyspnea related to worsening bilateral pleural effusions. Left thorascopic pleural biospy and talc pleurodesis were performed on ___. Pleural biopsy showed: "Extensive granulation tissue along with mesothelial proliferation and hemosiderin-laden macrophages are seen, consistent with the chronicity of the effusive process is present.  No morphological evidence of large cell transformation or infection is seen.  The morphology, supported by the concurrent flow cytometry immunophenotyping ___: CD20 dim, CD5-positive, CD23-positive, lambda light chain expression) is consistent with a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma." Again, CLL was felt to be a "bystander" and not the cause of the pleural effusion. Of note, convalescent serum samples subsequently returned showing a rise in ___ B5 antibody to a level of 32. Molecular analyses for Erlichia were negative on pleural tissue. He felt improved after talc pleurodesis. (9) With progressive symptomatic anemia and thrombocytopenia, he began his first chemotherapy for CLL on ___, receiving  cycle #1 of fludarabine/Cytoxan (without rituximab). On ___, when peripheral blood lymphocytes declined below 50K, he received his first dose of Rituxin, given over 2 days. Further therapy with Fludara/Cytoxan was held due to persistent thrombocytopenia. On ___, with persistent thrombocytopenia, he began weekly Rituxin X 4 with vincristine and prednisone 100 mg daily x5  added to Rituxin on ___, followed by prednisone taper for presumed ITP. With subsequent improvement in platelet counts, he received R-CVP from ___ to ___. On ___, with substantial recovery in all blood counts, he received FCR, with FC administered on days 1 and 2, not day 3. Full-dose cycle ___ FCR was administered on days 1 through 3 beginning ___. (10)Due to worsening anemia and thrombocytopenia thought to be secondary to ITP as well as bone marrow involvement with CLL, he received a pulse of high-dose dexamethasone at the beginning of ___ with 4 doses of weekly rituximab and weekly vincristine on weeks 2 through 4 ___ through ___. On ___, he began daily prednisone instead of dexamethasone pulsing. Thrombocytopenia improved but anemia persisted. (11) On ___, he began Campath subcutaneously in an attempt to further unload CLL from bone marrow. On ___, after five Campath doses, Campath was held secondary to WBC 0.4 with ANC  297 and increased anemia and thrombocytopenia. He received one week of weekly rituximab on ___. (12) Hospitalized ___ to ___ with febrile neutropenia attributed to viral infection. Blood cultures, urine culture,  CMV viral load, adenovirus PCR, EBV PCR, Parvo 19 DNA negative and HHV-8 PCR and respiratory viral screen and cultures were all negative. Received Cefime and  Neupogen with resolution of fever. ___ woman with an unusual recent medical history related  to pseudoaneurysm of the intra- and extrahepatic arteries.  She  was hospitalized initially for bleeding from a ruptured pseudoaneurysm, treated with an interventional radiology embolization to the  left aneurysm.  The remaining right hepatic artery pseudoaneurysm thrombosed on its own.  She has been recovering well from this, but has had imaging findings concerning for thickening of the gallbladder.  She came in with several hours of new acute right upper quadrant pain.  Imaging demonstrated disruption of the gallbladder wall contained within the surrounding inflammatory rind.  Concerns for gallbladder ischemia were raised.  Given her clinical picture, elevated white count to 18, and imaging findings, open cholecystectomy was recommended for suspected ischemic gallbladder necrosis. Given the significant  inflammation around the gallbladder and concern for possible adhesions to her extrahepatic arterial aneurysms, laparoscopic approach was not recommended.  Risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure were discussed in detail and appropriate consents were signed. Treated with rituximab in ___. -CAD s/p stent ___. -herniated disc s/p surgery ___. -s/p R and L knee replacement -BPH  Oncologic hx:  Diagnosed with melanoma of the left shoulder and underwent excision (stage IB, ___ level IV) in ___. In ___, he developed an episode of word finding difficulty that lasted for a few minutes. MRI Head was done on ___ and showed a left frontal mass. CT Chest was subsequently performed and showed 4 lung nodules, the largest measuring 2.3 cm. CT Abdomen showed borderline splenomegaly and no evidence of metastatic disease. A follow-up MRI Head on ___ showed a 3.4 x 3.9 x  2.7 cm heterogeneously enhancing, necrotic mass in the left inferior frontal lobe region of Broca's area. Dr. ___ left frontal craniotomy and resection of the mass at ___ on  ___, with pathology confirming metastatic melanoma (positive for MART-1, S-100, and HMB-45). The specimen showed a BRAF V600 mutation by PCR.   Post-resection MRIs on ___ and ___ revealed peripheral enhancement along the resection cavity. On ___, he underwent Gamma Knife radiosurgery to the tumor resection cavity. The MRI done for the Gamma Knife also showed a second small metastasis  in the left parietal lobe, adjacent to the sagittal sinus, and this second lesion was also treated with Gamma Knife. Both lesions were treated to 20 Gy.  He continued his care with Dr. ___ at ___ and also met with Dr. ___ at ___ on ___ for a second  opinion. He was recommended combination BRAF/MEK inhibition with dabrafenib and trametinib and started the medications in  ___. He continued to have surveillance imaging. CT Torso on ___ showed overall stability of 7 pulmonary nodules, the largest measuring 1.6 cm. There were also multiple small mediastinal lymph nodes stable in size. However, CT Head on ___ showed  an enlarging lesion in the left parietal lobe from 0.8 cm to 2 cm. MRI Brain was done on the same date and showed significant enlargement of the left parietal lobe mass that was previously treated with Gamma Knife, with surrounding vasogenic edema.  He underwent craniotomy and resection of the left parietal mass on ___ with Dr. ___ at ___. He did well ___. Post-operative MRI showed gross total  resection of the mass lesion without other new lesions. However, invasion of the dura was seen. Pathology was consistent with metastatic melanoma, BRAF V600 mutated. His case was discussed at the ___ Neuro-oncology Tumor Board. Given prior Gamma Knife to the lesion, it was demed a Gamma Knife failure and there is no plan for additional Gamma Knife. Whole brain radiotherapy was discussed, but given the patient's age, it was felt not to be a good option given the potential toxicities.  He continued on dabrafenib and trametinib and had periodic restaging CT and MRI. His most recent MRI Head on ___ showed  a 1.4 x 1.1 x 1.3 cm masslike enhancement within the left parietal lobe adjacent to the prior resection bed. CT Torso on the same date showed several stable left lung nodules and no other areas concerning for metastatic disease. Per patient report, he was noted to have incidental finding of intestinalis pneumonitis  that has been present for the past year for which Dr. ___ is considering further workup. He was evaluated again at ___ Neurosurgery with plan for Gamma Knife. Repeat scan identified  an additional smaller lesion anteriorly involving the falx. He received Gamma Knife 20 cGy to each of the 2 lesions on ___.  He continued on dabrafenib and trametinib with repeat brain imaging showing 7 new punctate lesions. He underwent Gamma Knife again to these lesions in ___.  PET scan on ___ continued to show stable disease.    Social History: ___ Family History: Mother - died of breast cancer.

___ yo morbidly obese male with history of DM II, CAD s/p CABG,  chronic bilateral lymphedema, and obesity hypoventilation  syndrome presented with intermittent LUQ abdominal pain.  He  initially presented to the OSH with fever to 102.9, and a sharp,  intense, stabbing pain awoke him from sleep.  It was initially  LUQ pain but radiated to the RUQ.  He took a double dose of his  pain medication and the pain went away.  He tried to avoid pain  medication later in the day, but the pain came back.  He also  notes red extremities, but denies cough, SOB, CP, nausea,  vomiting, dysuria, or diarrhea.  He presented to the OSH for  this acute worsening of his abdominal pain.  He was found to  have a transaminitis with an elevated lipase.  His urine was  clear after antibiotics. Zosyn was started for empiric coverage  of his cellulitic process and for intraabdominal coverage.  He  was given Dilaudid with subsequent somnolence.  ABG at that time  revealed 7.28/81/52/38.  All narcotics were held and he was  placed on BiPap with subsequent improvement.    . His hospital course continued with his respiratory status helped  some by diuresis.  The next morning he was pain free but his  bilirubin continued to climb from 2.6 upon admission.  Now, his  pain has returned in the RUQ though not particularly severe.   Bilirubin now 4.5, AlkPhos 185, with a mild transamnitis  (60s-80s).  GI saw him at ___ and they were unwilling to  intervene. Denies nausea,  vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, or changes in bowel habits.  Denies dysuria, frequency, or urgency. Denies arthralgias or  myalgias. Denies rashes or skin changes. ___ with h/o type 2 diabetes, cirrhosis secondary to hep C (s/p  PEG-IFN and ribavirin ___ and EtOH abuse (in remission since  ___, found to have HCC in ___ (s/p cypberknife in ___ and  RFA ___ who presents with 3 days of RUQ abd pain, nausea, and  vomiting. In the ED, the pain was described as sharp, severe,  epigastric and RUQ, does not radiate to back, comes and goes in  waves on a scale of minutes, and has not moved over the past 3  days. He got partial relief from 15mg oxycodone and 1 lorazepam  the day prior to admission. He states he has noticed some  associated abdominal distension over the past 3 days with  associated SOB ___ this distention. Vomitus has been  clear/yellow, non-bloody, with no coffee grounds appearance. No  diarrhea; states opioid associated constipation is at his  current baseline, last BM day prior to admission. States that he  has baseline neuropathic leg pain which is unchanged.     In the ED, initial VS were 10 98.1 104 149/81 20 98% RA    Exam notable for moderately distended abdomen, soft, no  guarding, with pt reported tenderness to RUQ. CTAB. Tachy,  regular. No peripheral edema. A&Ox3. No asterixis.    Labs showed: WBC 7.2 Hgb 15.2 Plts 84; Cr 0.8;    ALT 87, AST 120, AP: 194, Tbili 11.4 (Dbili 7.5), Alb 3.8, INR  1.3; Lipase 1627, lactate 2.3    Imaging showed:   ___ No acute intrathoracic process.  ___ RUQ US: No definite findings to explain patient's  symptoms. The liver is cirrhotic, as before. Known hepatic  masses are poorly visualized. The main portal vein is patent  with hepatopetal flow. Splenomegaly. There is no intrahepatic  biliary dilation.      Patient received:    ___ 14:56 IV Ondansetron 4 mg    ___ 14:56 IV Morphine Sulfate 4 mg    ___ 17:07 IV Morphine Sulfate 4 mg    ___ 17:50 IVF 1000 mL LR 1000 mL    ___ 18:05 TD Nicotine Patch 14 mg    ___ 21:27 IV Morphine Sulfate 4 mg    ___ 21:27 IV Ondansetron 4 mg    Transfer VS were 6 98.6 75 116/78 16 95% RA    Heme/onc was consulted in the ED and per ED ___, recommended  consulting interventional GI / ERCP after RUQ US.    Decision was made to admit to medicine for further management.     On arrival to the floor, patient reports reasonably well  controlled epigastric and RUQ pain, no nausea, feels anxious.   This morning he states that pain is well controlled. He appears  mildly anxious, stating that he was told he has an "obstruction"  and has since been fixated on that and has been trying to have a  bowel movement to solve the obstruction. He states that his  abdomen has been distended for the past year, which he believes  causes his shortness of breath. When asked to describe his pain  in the past couple of days, he draws a box and scribbles all  over the page. Ms ___ is a ___ with h/o lung and breast cancer (both in  remission) who p/w abdominal pain and ___ days of vomiting, as  well as chills. Denies  diarrhea or dysuria. This pain came on  suddenly ~1 week ago, initially was more diffuse but did  localize to the RUQ and epigastrum. Initially went to ___  ___, was found to have obstructive LFT pattern; RUQ US then  showed suggestion of choledocholithiasis so transferred here for  ERCP. She was given unasyn at ___  Initial vitals in ___ ED were 97.8 69 116/75 15 98% RA and  have remained stable. Given unasyn and vancomycin IV. Labs  showed obstructive LFTs though already downtrending, and  elevated lipase  RUQ US in our ED shows: 1. Cholelithiasis with gallbladder wall thickening, concerning  for cholecystitis. Recommend correlation with symptomatology, and  consider a HIDA scan if there is persistent clinical concern for  acute cholecystitis. 2. Normal CBD diameter, measuring 5 mm.  ACS consulted and will consider CCY once LFTs normalize this  admission.   She then went to ERCP, which showed: Normal major papilla.  - Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and deep with a  sphincterotome using a free-hand technique.  - The CBD and CHD measured 5mm in diameter.  - The left and right hepatics and intrahepatics were  non-dilated.  - There was a possible filling defect consistent with sludge  noted in the distal CBD.  - Otherwise there was no evidence of strictures or stones.  - The cystic duct and neck of the gallbladder was opacified and  well visualized.   - Balloon sweeps were performed of the common bile duct which  yielded scant sludge.  - Further sweeps were performed until no debris was noted.  - Completion occlusion cholangiogram revealed no further filling  defects.    Upon arrival to the floor, she is feeling better and has no  pain. She denies dysuria, cough or diarrhea. Her LFTs resolved  spontaneously as an outpatient after her last admission. She had  a normal lipase at that time. Choledocholithiasis with 1 cm obstructing stone and layering   sludge in the distal common bile duct with marked extrahepatic  and intrahepatic biliary dilation diffusely. Hyperenhancing  common bile duct can be seen with cholangitis. 2. Distended gallbladder containing gallstones with thickened  hyperemic wall and surrounding pericholecystic fluid compatible  with acute cholecystitis. 3. No evidence of perforation or abscess.  CXR 1. Left lower lobe opacity could represent pneumonia or possibly  be due to atelectasis in the setting of low lung volumes. Repeat  PA and lateral at full inspiration could help clarify.  2. This is a ___ yo M with late stage Alzheimer's, CAD, anemia, who  is being sent to ___ from ___ with lethargy, fevers to  101.6 and hypotension to the 65/37. Per ___ notes, he had a  syncopal episode yesterday, which prompted his MD to stop  lisinopril, and then was found to be hypotensive this AM. BS  there was 161. There is no other information able to be provided  by the patient, as at baseline, he is severely demented.   .   On arrival to the ED, the patient's vitals were T 99.6R BP 70/38  HR 76 R 20 98%3L. He was given 4.5L NS with no response in his  BP. His labs were notable for new acute renal failure, a  leukocytosis to 12,000, bicarb of 20, lactate of 1.4 and normal  LFT's. CE's were elevated, trop to 0.17 in the setting of sepsis  and renal failure. The patient had a penile prosthesis and was  unable to be catheterized in the ED for a UA. A bedside bladder  scan showed several hundred cc's in the bladder but no  distention and urology was called. A CXR was unremarkable, CT  abd/pelvis did not show free air/stranding, and an EKG was  paced. The ED wanted to place a CVL to initiate pressors for  septic shock, but the family reiterated the patient's wishes for  DNR/DNI and no procedures, however okayed peripheral pressors  and ICU admission for 24 hours. He was started on levophed, but  became bradycardic, so was switched to dopamine for ?cardiogenic  shock. He was given a dose of vanco/zosyn and admitted to the  MICU for further management.   .   On arrival to the ICU, the patient is screaming out, eyes  closed. ROS unable to be obtained.      Past Medical History: 1. Coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass  graft.   2. Cervical spondylosis, wears soft collar at baseline.   3. Prostate cancer - "watchful waiting"   4. BPH status post prostatectomy.   4. Degenerative joint disease.   5. Hypothyroidism.   6. Sleep apnea.   7. Dementia   8. Recent left eye surgery c/b endopthalmitis      Social History: ___ ___ History: Mother - CHF   Father - died ___ age ___   no history of syncope, arrythmia

This was a ___ woman who in ___ of this year had been admitted to an outside institution with severe left lower quadrant discomfort. A CT scan at that time showed several fluid collections in association with the sigmoid colon with inflammatory changes suggestive of a contained perforation. She recovered with antibiotic therapy. The fluid collections resolved. An attempt at colonoscopy was performed but a sigmoid stricture could not be traversed. A virtual colonoscopy was then obtained. She did not appear to have any obvious mucosal lesions. Thickening of the sigmoid colon was described. The patient then sought a second opinion here the ___. I suggested to her that she undergo definitive colectomy. I would determine at the time of surgery whether there was any concern for neoplasia, and if so, her mesenteric dissection would be extended. She had no mass lesions in the liver on CT scan or anything suggestive of carcinomatosis or ascites. There was no mesenteric adenopathy. She had a history of heavy cigarette smoking and her surgery had actually been cancelled 3 weeks earlier because of an episode of left-sided presumed pneumonia, responsive to Zithromax. She now had returned to her baseline pulmonary status. A preoperative CEA was 10 and the CA-125 was normal. She had a normal chest x- ray prior to the episode of pneumonia. I thought it most likely that the mild elevation of the CEA was related to her chronic cigarette smoking and perhaps residual sigmoid inflammation. ___ yo F s/p lap supracervical hysterectomy for fibroids in ___ at the ___ presents with 3 days of LLQ pain. She describes the pain as similar to a pain that she had been having since her original operation but only a much more extremely severe version of this. Her previous pain had been attributed to a L dermoid ovarian cyst seen at the time of her hysterectomy in ___. No treatment was recommended for the cyst.   The pain is severe in nature, sharp and radiates through the lower abdomen. Helped by lying still and with narcotics, worse with movement. Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of depression, anxiety, asthma, eczema, and severe hidradenitis suppurativa s/p multiple rectal surgeries, who presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain for 1 month.  He reports that the diarrhea started approximately 1 month ago. He is having up to 15-stools per day, described as "rust  colored" and occasionally with small amounts of blood. He was seen  ___ at ___ where he was diagnosed with colitis by CT scan. He was discharged on a 7-day course of ciprofloxacin which he  completed, however he states the diarrhea persisted. He also has noted diffuse lower abdominal pain, particularly in the LLQ, described as sharp/stabbing and intermittent but daily. The pain has not improved with Tramadol and tizanidine. He does not feel like his current pain and symptoms are similar to the prior times he has had rectal and perirectal abscesses. He started feeling subjectively warm and had two episodes of non-bloody,  non-bilious vomiting ___ days prior to admission. He is now concerned that  he "is septic." Does not report fevers, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, or urinary symptoms. He does not report any antibiotics prior to the diarrhea or any recent travel or abnormal ingestions.  In the ED, initial VS were:  98.8 107 149/97 18 98% RA. Exam notable for: General - comfortable, non-toxic, no acute distress GI - abdomen soft, diffuse tenderness most pronounced in the  LLQ, no rebound or guarding, bowel sounds active, well-healed colostomy scar to the left of midline Rectal - large area of erythema with multiple superficial abrasions around rectum, very tender to palpation, no palpable mass or fluctuant mass, no purulent drainage  Labs showed:  WBC 13.9, 74% PMNs. Cr 0.8, HCO3 25, K 4.4. LFTs wnl. negative UA.  Imaging showed:  CT A/P: 1. Wall thickening and significant  fatty stranding of the distal descending and proximal sigmoid colon over an 11 cm segment consistent with colitis. Given pattern and extent of inflammation, colonoscopy should be performed after treatment. 2. Foci of air noted adjacent to the bowel more likely to be in diverticula rather than microperforation. 3. No drainable fluid collections are noted.  Surgery was consulted and stated: No acute surgical issues.  Would recommend admit to medicine for monitoring, NPO, GI workup for IBD, ABx, C.diff testing.  Patient received: 1L IVF, 4 mg IV morphine x 3, IV  Ciprofloxacin, Simvastatin 40 mg, 2 mg lorazepam, 50 mg atenolol, 25 mg diphenhydramine, 4 mg IV Zofran.  Transfer VS were:  98.3 81 118/62 18 94% RA.  On arrival to the floor, patient confirmed the above history. He is currently most bothered by his rectal pain, which he states  is severe. It will occur after a bowel movement and last for  several hours. Given the frequency of his bowel movements, the pain generally does not go away. On review of systems, does not  report fevers, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, and changes in bladder habits.      Past Medical History: Hidradenitis suppurativa DM Eczema Depression HTN HLD Panic attacks   Social History: ___ Family History: Father: Multiple myeloma and lymphoma Mother: ___ cancer

He was admitted to ___ as noted above. Since his discharge, he  has continued to have minimal po intake. She notes that he was  having poor po intake while in ___ but that it is worse  now.
